item.title: Live Updates: Hurricane Melissa Turns Toward the Bahamas After Battering Cuba and Jamaica
item.description: The storm weakened as it passed over Cuba and moved toward the Bahamas with 100 m.p.h. winds. In Jamaica, 70 percent of the country is without power, hampering damage assessments.

item.title: Annabel Goldsmith, a Queen of British High Society, Dies at 91
item.description: Annabel’s, the club that Ms. Goldsmith’s first husband named after her, opened in the 1960s and is still one of London’s most exclusive nightspots.

item.title: How Japan’s New Prime Minister Bonded With Trump
item.description: Trump will meet Japan’s new prime minister, Sanae Takaichi, on Tuesday (10/28). A look at how she will approach President Trump in order to rekindle the close relationship he had with her mentor, former Prime Minister Shinzo Abe.

item.title: France Adds Consent to Its Rape Law After Yearslong Fight
item.description: The new legislation was adopted after dozens of men were convicted of raping Gisèle Pelicot while she was drugged by her husband.

item.title: As China and U.S. Split Over Energy, Korea Is Stuck in the Middle
item.description: It needs the United States for defense and has spent billions building factories in America. But a Trump trade deal this week with China could erase a Korean edge in the U.S. market.

item.title: Protests in Tanzania as Voters Head to the Polls
item.description: The East African country’s Party of Revolution, one of the longest-ruling parties on the continent, seeks to keep its grip on power.

item.title: Israeli Strikes in Gaza Kill at Least 100, Local Health Officials Say
item.description: After what appeared to be the deadliest day since a truce deal was agreed on this month, Israel said the cease-fire had resumed.

item.title: U.S. Says It Will Cut Troops in Eastern Europe
item.description: About 700 troops are expected to be withdrawn as Trump administration officials shift resources to the Indo-Pacific region.

item.title: Life Lessons from (Very Old) Bowhead Whales
item.description: A gene that helped bowheads adapt to frigid Arctic waters also granted them extraordinary longevity. Could it help aging humans become more resilient?

item.title: Putin Announces Test of Tsunami-Making Nuclear Weapon
item.description: The test comes days after President Vladimir V. Putin announced the previous trial of another Russian nuclear weapon.

item.title: U.S. Middle East Envoy Presses Lebanon to Disarm Hezbollah
item.description: The visit by the envoy, Morgan Ortagus, coincided with a spike in Israeli attacks on Hezbollah in recent weeks that has stoked fears of a renewed conflict.

item.title: Feted as a Peacemaker in South Korea, Trump Vows to End Hostilities With North Korea
item.description: President Trump lamented not being able to speak with Mr. Kim, the North Korean leader, but vowed to end the decades of hostilities between the two Koreas.

item.title: In Photos: Trump’s Asia Trip
item.description: He has played the roles of dealmaker, peacemaker and showman, on a tour filled with pomp and circumstance.

item.title: A River Restoration in Oregon Gets Fast Results: The Salmon Swam Right Back
item.description: The fish had been missing from the headwaters of the Klamath River for more than a century. Just a year after the removal of a final dam, they’ve returned.

item.title: U.N. Climate Adaptation Report Shows Declining Money for Climate Disasters
item.description: In 2021, rich countries vowed to spend more to help poor countries adapt to warming. That goal is unlikely to be met, a new report finds.

item.title: Mercedes Reports a Drop in Profit but Maintains Its Forecast
item.description: The German carmaker held its outlook steady and said it would buy back more than $2 billion in shares, as sales of its high-end models improved.

item.title: Small Island Nations Lack Funds to Fight Climate Disasters
item.description: As Hurricane Melissa threatens island nations across the Caribbean, many are already burdened by debt from a string of climate-fueled crises.

item.title: How the Opium War Still Shapes Xi Jinping’s Trade Clash With Trump
item.description: China’s leader draws on lessons from Lin Zexu, a Qing official whose defiance of Britain led to China’s humiliating defeat but made him a national hero.

item.title: China Outlines 5-Year Plan to Double Down on Global Tech Ambitions
item.description: Ahead of a meeting with President Trump, China’s leader signaled that he is committed to competing in manufacturing and technology despite tensions with Washington.

item.title: Street Battles Rage in Ukrainian City After Russian Troops Enter Stronghold
item.description: Moscow’s forces infiltrated Pokrovsk after months of attacks on the city, a strategic part of Ukraine’s eastern defenses.

item.title: The Netherlands’ Election Is a Referendum on the Far Right
item.description: Geert Wilders and his far-right party blew up the Dutch governing coalition this year. Will that cost their party seats in Parliament?

item.title: As the Dutch Vote, One Issue Carries the Day: Affordable Housing
item.description: The small European nation of 18 million people is in the middle of its worst housing crunch in decades. But there is no quick political solution.

item.title: Hurricane Melissa’s Direct Hit Knocks Most of Jamaica Offline
item.description: Most of the island of two million people was without internet service, and major airports were closed. Kingston, the capital, was mostly spared.

item.title: South Korea Gifts Trump a Replica of an Ancient Gold Crown
item.description: President Trump received a replica of a golden crown excavated from an ancient royal tomb in Gyeongju. He called it “very special.”

item.title: Vietnam Prevents BBC Journalist From Leaving the Country
item.description: The reporter’s passport has been held by the authorities since August. Rights advocates want British officials to raise the issue with Vietnam’s visiting leader.

item.title: Japan Plans to Send Troops to Help Stop Bear Attacks
item.description: With the number of people killed by bears reaching a record nationwide, the defense ministry is preparing to send the military to one badly hit area to set traps.

item.title: Sudan’s Military Withdraws From El Fasher in Darfur, Handing City to R.S.F.
item.description: The Sudanese military withdrew from a key city in Darfur, where fleeing civilians were reported to be coming under attack from R.S.F. paramilitary forces.

item.title: When Caregiving Makes Women Ill
item.description: Eastern Europeans have migrated in droves to take care of Italy’s aged and infirm. Then they started getting sick, with an ailment dubbed ‘Italy syndrome.’

item.title: New Crack at an Ancient Puzzle Reignites Debate for Archaeologists
item.description: It is clear that the sprawling city of Teotihuacan near Mexico City was a major metropolis of the ancient world, but what do all those glyphs mean?

item.title: Trump’s Hand in Argentina
item.description: The president’s intervention on behalf of Argentina’s leader fits into a long history of American involvement in the elections of other countries.

item.title: Netanyahu Orders Strikes in Gaza, as Israel Says Hamas Violated Cease-Fire
item.description: The office of the Israeli prime minister said Tuesday evening that he had ordered “forceful strikes,” accusing Hamas of firing on Israeli troops and failing to return hostages’ bodies.

item.title: North Korea Conducts Missile Test Ahead of Trump Visit to South
item.description: The country has yet to respond to President Trump’s overtures to meet again with Kim Jong-un, its leader.

item.title: South Korea’s Gyeongju Scrambles to Host Trump, Xi and More Leaders at APEC
item.description: The authorities have been scrambling to accommodate this year’s Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum in Gyeongju, which is known for tombs, temples and pagodas.

item.title: 10 Accused of Cyberbullying France’s First Lady Stand Trial. Here’s What to Know.
item.description: Brigitte Macron filed a criminal complaint in Paris after claims about her gender and her relationship with President Emmanuel Macron went viral. The accused deny wrongdoing.

item.title: At Least 64 Dead in Rio de Janeiro as Brazilian Police Crack Down on Drug Gangs
item.description: The authorities said the deadliest operation in Rio’s history had killed four police officers and at least 60 other people. It was an attack on “narco-terrorists,” the state governor said.

item.title: Hurricane Melissa Hits Jamaica as One of the Most Powerful on Record
item.description: The Category 5 storm, whose sustained wind speeds surpassed those of Hurricane Katrina, peeled roofs off homes, swelled rivers and drew dire warnings from officials.

item.title: U.S. Military Kills 14 More People Accused of Smuggling Drugs on Boats
item.description: Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth said that the three strikes hit four boats in international waters and that there had been one survivor.

item.title: Father-Son Bonding at 2 Miles Per Minute on Germany’s Fabled Autobahn
item.description: Late for a rock concert, dads’ rules about driving are (legally) broken as the speedometer hits 125 m.p.h. on a highway where there are no speed limits.

item.title: Once Again: The Pope Likes That Other Chicago Team, Not the Cubs
item.description: Although he posed with a Cubs jersey on Monday, a gift from a religious leader also from Chicago, Pope Leo is a longtime fan of the Chicago White Sox. Some people can’t seem to keep it straight.

item.title: Britain Plans to Convert Two Military Bases to House Asylum Seekers
item.description: The government has been under pressure to shut down hotels accommodating migrants as public anger rises.

item.title: Israel Conducts First Airstrike in West Bank in Months and Kills 3
item.description: A militant group allied with Hamas confirmed the deaths, which were part of an increase in fighting in the Palestinian territory during a surge of settler violence.

item.title: Trump’s Feud With Colombian Leader Threatens U.S. Antidrug Efforts
item.description: President Trump said he is cutting U.S. aid. Gustavo Petro, a leftist guerrilla turned president, has called Mr. Trump’s boat strikes murder.

item.title: As Trump Tariffs Canada, Carney Turns to Asia for Trade
item.description: Mark Carney is pitching Canada as a predictable and responsible alternative to the United States.

item.title: On the Menu for Trump in Tokyo: American Rice
item.description: Rice is a point of pride in Japan, and the choice was a break from the typical diplomatic practice of showcasing local ingredients.

item.title: A Tidy Dutch Town Offers a Window Into a Messy Dutch Election
item.description: Two years after a shock win for the far-right Geert Wilders, the Netherlands is returning to the polls. His hometown shows the pain points of the country’s volatile politics.

item.title: Jamaica’s Beach Towns and Fishing Villages Brace for Hurricane Melissa
item.description: Stranded vacationers on the island, which depends on tourism, used their beds to block their windows in case the powerful storm shattered the glass.

item.title: More Food Reaches Gaza, but It’s Still Not Enough
item.description: Aid to the devastated territory has increased since the cease-fire took effect and prices have fallen. But many trucks going into Gaza are bringing food and commercial goods to sell that most people cannot afford.

item.title: Japanese Man Admits to Assassinating Former Prime Minister Shinzo Abe
item.description: Tetsuya Yamagami, 45, is accused of assassinating Mr. Abe with a homemade gun during an election rally in 2022.

item.title: Rebranding Immigration
item.description: India wants to send its vast work force abroad. It may have found a way around a word that stokes opposition in many countries.

item.title: Beyond Trade War, China’s Xi Looks to Press Trump on Taiwan
item.description: China’s leader wants to weaken American support for Taiwan. But first he will want clarity about President Trump’s stance toward the island.

item.title: Milei’s Win in Argentina Signals Rebuke of the Past and Trump’s Impact
item.description: President Javier Milei emerged from the election with an even tighter bond with the United States and a bigger mandate to pass transformative economic plans.

item.title: Ivory Coast President Secures 4th Term in Election Without Top Opponents
item.description: President Alassane Ouattara won 89.77 percent of the vote, but critics called the elections flawed after two main challengers were barred from running.

item.title: The U.N.’s food agency says cutbacks forced it to send fewer meals to storm zones.
